title: 115_hr3394
content: The Act may be cited as the "Teaching Health Centers Graduate Medical Education Extension Act of 2017". The Congress enacted the program of payments to teaching health centers for graduate medical education in 2010 to address the shortage of primary care physicians, especially in rural and underserved areas. Teaching health center residents and faculty are expected to provide over one million primary care medical visits in 2017 to underserved communities. Residents who train at teaching health centers are more likely to practice primary care and stay in underserved or rural areas compared to traditional Medicare GME residents. The teaching health center program is crucial for training the next generation of primary care providers. The teaching health center program plays a vital role in training primary care physicians and addressing the physician shortage. It is crucial to continue funding the program at a sustainable level to ensure the training of future primary care providers. Reauthorization of program for teaching health centers with graduate medical education programs. Reauthorization of program for teaching health centers with graduate medical education programs. Payments under section 340H of the Public Health Service Act for maintenance, expansion, and establishment of approved graduate medical residency training programs. In fiscal years 2019 and 2020, payments will be made for up to 60 and 120 full-time equivalent residents, respectively, at new approved graduate medical residency programs. Priority will be given to qualified teaching health centers serving health professional shortage areas. In fiscal years 2019 and 2020, payments will be made for up to 60 and 120 full-time equivalent residents at new approved graduate medical residency programs. Priority will be given to qualified teaching health centers serving health professional shortage areas. The number of residents for which a qualified teaching health center receives payments shall not exceed by more than six the number of residents for the preceding fiscal year. Funding for these programs is outlined in subsection (g) of the Public Health Service Act. The Public Health Service Act is amended to allocate funding for existing and new programs, with specific amounts earmarked for fiscal years 2018, 2019, and 2020. Additionally, a limit of 5 percent of the allocated amount is set for administrative expenses. The Public Health Service Act is amended to allocate funding for programs, with limits on administrative expenses. Annual reporting requirements include data on patients treated by residents and their entry into primary care practice. The Public Health Service Act is amended to allocate funding for programs, with reporting requirements on residents entering primary care practice in underserved areas or rural locations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must report on training costs for approved graduate medical residency programs by March 31, 2020. Amendments are made to the definition of new approved graduate medical residency training programs. Amendments are made to the definition of new approved graduate medical residency training programs, including technical corrections to the Public Health Service Act. Redesignating the second section 340H as section 340I, while payments for previous fiscal years under the first section 340H of the Public Health Service Act will continue to apply for fiscal years before 2018.
